Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Electronic Doping in Semiconductor Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves a collaboration between two research groups at the University of Minnesota (UMN) and one from the University of Duisburg-Essen in Germany (UDE). The goal of the research is to synthesize and study nanometer-scale semiconductor crystallites (or nanocrystals) in which impurities (or dopants) have been incorporated by design. Even without such dopants, semiconductor nanocrystals can exhibit unusual and useful physical phenomena due to their small size. The critical role that dopants play in semiconductor devices such as the transistor provides a strong motivation to study doped semiconductor nanocrystals. Doping can also address key problems in nanocrystal applications from solar cells to bio-imaging. As semiconductor nanocrystals already have commercial applications (e.g., in bio-imaging) and more on the horizon (e.g., tunable lasers, light emitting diodes, and solar cells), the research should provide further control over the properties of a useful class of materials. The collaboration includes researchers at UMN who are experts in solution-based synthesis of nanocrystals and at UDE who are experts in the chemical vapor synthesis of nanocrystals and their characterization using the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) technique. Project objectives include (i) the development of solution- and chemical-vapor-synthetic-methods to prepare doped nanocrystals and (ii) the use of EXAFS in conjunction with reverse Monte Carlo (RMC) simulations to determine the location of the dopant. A better understanding of the doping process should result.

In addition to the scientific goals, a major aim of this Materials World Network project is to provide future scientists with unique international research experiences. Students with such experiences benefit firsthand from observing how science bridges international differences. During the course of the project, 6 undergraduates and three graduate students from UMN will travel to Germany to perform research at UDE. For the undergraduate students, this will be incorporated into a research abroad summer program. For the graduate students, this can be arranged at a convenient time during their thesis project. Similarly, students from UDE will travel to UMN. These exchanges can also be facilitated by visits of UDE researchers to the US to perform EXAFS experiments at central beam lines (e.g., at Argonne National Laboratory). These visits will allow additional interactions between team members as well as analysis of samples prepared both at UMN and UDE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanocrystals exhibit fascinating properties that often depend on the size of the crystal and differ substantially from those of the corresponding bulk solid. As a result there continues to be great interest in using nanocrystals for applications ranging from biological sensors and catalysts to optoelectronic devices such as video displays. In microelectronic devices such as transistors, bulk semiconductor electrical properties are controlled by the purposeful incorporation (doping) of impurity elements. The primary goal of this National Science Foundation grant was to prepare electronically doped nanocrystals, characterize their structure and properties and incorporate them into working electronic devices.

Six examples of electronically doped semiconductor nanocrystals were successfully prepared and characterized. The preparative methods ranged from easy (cadmium or lead selenide doped with silver ions) to challenging (cadmium selenide doped with aluminum or indium). The most critical aspect of the work was developing methods to establish that the impurity atoms were located within the nanocrystal as opposed to adsorbed on it’s surface. A variety of spectroscopic, microscopic and analytical methods provided strong evidence that the dopants were indeed located within the nanocrystal. One unexpected result of the doping was found in the silver-doped cadmium selenide. Small amounts of silver (~ 3 silver atoms per nanocrystal) caused a striking increase in fluorescence yield. Figure 1 shows a photograph demonstrating this effect. The cause of the increased fluorescence was proposed to be due to the presence of a positive charge on the silver dopant as a result of it acting as an n-type donor located in an interstitial position within the cadmium selenide lattice. At higher silver concentrations the effect was reversed consistent with the silver substituting for cadmium in the lattice and becoming a p-type dopant. For this example and for each of the other dopant/semiconductor systems, nanocrystal transistors were prepared. In all cases characteristic electrical behavior was observed that was attributed to the presence of the dopant.

Because of the interest in doped nanocrystals for applications, the broader impact of this grant included enabling researchers and developers in other fields, such as electrical engineering, to design and construct devices with new materials and improved properties. It is equally important to recognize that three Ph. D. thesis projects were largely supported by this grant and that these graduates have continued their development in postdoctoral research and expect to enter the job market in academia or industry in a STEM discipline. In addition four undergraduates conducted research both in our University of Minnesota laboratories and in the laboratory of our collaborator at the University of Duisburg-Essen in Germany. Not only did this allow them to learn new laboratory skills, but it also enriched them through the exposure of a different culture.
